chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So that no one thinks any human sins can be hidden from God, let's learn from the words of Saint Job, who says: "You have counted my thoughts, and none of my sins have been hidden from you. You have sealed my iniquities in a bag and noted if I have erred unwillingly." (Job 14:16-17, according to the Septuagint).

And let no one think they will escape punishment if they refuse to repent. Listen carefully to the words of this same holy man, who says: "Indeed, let no one who is wicked believe they will go unpunished, no matter how much they provoke God in their anger, as if there will be no investigation into it."

Therefore, in Ecclesiasticus, a helpful warning is given, so that we lack neither the conversion to avoid sins nor the prayer to forgive past ones. For it is said: "My son, have you sinned? Do not do it again; but also pray for your past sins so that they may be forgiven." "Flee from sins as you would from the face of a serpent. If you approach them, they will take hold of you, and like a lion's teeth, they will kill you by devouring you." (Ecclesiasticus 21:1-2).

It is also made clear that the impious and sinners who refuse to repent of their wickedness or iniquity will face eternal punishments in the end, but our Lord will grant mercy to those who have repented. For in the book of Ecclesiasticus, it is written: "For the Most High is merciful to those who repent, and will deliver vengeance upon the impious and sinners." (Ecclesiasticus 12:7).

Again, in the same book, it is said: "Remember that wrath will not delay. Humble your spirit greatly, for the vengeance on the flesh of the impious is fire and worms." (Ecclesiasticus 7:18-19).

Isaiah also says: "Their fire shall not be quenched, and their worm shall not die." (Isaiah 66:24).

Again in Ecclesiasticus, it is written: "The gathered flax of the congregation of sinners, and their end is a flame of fire. The way of sinners is full of offenses, and their end is hell, darkness, and punishments." (Ecclesiasticus 21:10-11).
chunks.original_latin:
Et ne quis putet aliqua peccata hominum latere
 Deum posse, sancti Job sermonibus instruamur dicentis:
Cogitationes meas dinumerasti, et nihil te latuit
peccatorum meorum. Signasti quasi  in sacculo
iniquitates meas, adnotasti si quid invitus erravi (Job
XIV, 16, 17, juxta LXX). Ne vero aliquis impunitum
se futurum putet, si converti noluerit, ejusdem sancti
viri verbis intentus auscultet dicentis: Imo vero
nullus confidat cum sit nequam, se impunitum futurum,
quidquid in iracundia provocet Deum, tanquam
inquisitio in eo non sit futura. Propter hoc in
Ecclesiastico salubris deprompta monitio, ut nec
conversio nobis desit qua vitentur peccata, nec deprecatio,
qua possint dimitti praeterita. Sic enim dicitur:
Fili, peccasti? Ne adjicias iterum; sed et de
pristinis deprecare, ut tibi dimittantur. Quasi a facie
 colubri fuge peccata. Si accesseris ad illa, suscipient
te, et quasi dentes leonis in vorando interficient te
(Eccli XXI 1 2). Sed nec illud siletur, quod impii
et peccatores qui poenitentiam impietatis sive iniquitatis
agere noluerint, aeternis sint in fine deputandi
suppliciis, misericordiam vero his qui poenitentiam
gesserint Dominus noster largiatur. Quippe in
libro Ecclesiastico sic positum est: Quoniam et Altissimus
misertus est poenitentibus, et impiis et peccatoribus
reddet vindictam (Eccli XII 7). Rursus in eodem
volumine sic dicitur: Memento quoniam ira non
tardabit. Humilia valde spiritum tuum, quoniam vindicta
 carnis impii ignis et vermis (Eccli VII 18 19). Esaias quoque dicit: Quia ignis eorum non exstinguetur,
et vermis eorum non morietur (Isai LXVI 24). Rursum in Ecclesiastico positum est: Stuppa collecta
synagoga peccantium, et consummatio eorum flamma
ignis. Via peccantium plena offensis, et in fine illorum
inferi, et tenebrae, et poenae (Eccli XXI 10 11).
